text: The arrival of Miss Eleanor Ainsworth in the village of Oakhaven was, to those accustomed to the predictable rhythms of rural life, an event of considerable, though largely unspoken, interest. Not that Miss Ainsworth possessed any striking beauty, or any particular fortune beyond a modest independence inherited from a distant aunt. It was rather the *manner* of her arrival, unaccompanied by any family member, and with a declared intention of establishing herself as a resident, that stirred a gentle current of speculation amongst the more observant households. Oakhaven, while not entirely averse to newcomers, preferred them attached, as it were, to a known quantity – a landed gentleman, a clergyman, or at least a respectable merchant. A single lady, however amiable, presented a slight disruption to the established order. Mrs. Penhaligon, whose own position as the wife of the local apothecary afforded her a certain authority on such matters, was amongst the first to call. She found Miss Ainsworth residing in a small, but perfectly adequate, cottage on the outskirts of the village, a property which had stood vacant for some years, and was generally considered
label: ai

text: rather too far from the church and the principal families to be truly desirable. Miss Ainsworth received her visitor with a composure that Mrs. Penhaligon found both pleasing and faintly unsettling. There was a directness in her gaze, and a lack of the customary diffidence one might expect from a lady settling into a new community, which suggested a spirit not easily swayed by the opinions of others. “I trust you found the journey agreeable, Miss Ainsworth?” Mrs. Penhaligon inquired, after the initial pleasantries had been exchanged. “Perfectly so, Mrs. Penhaligon,” Miss Ainsworth replied, her voice clear and modulated. “The roads were surprisingly well-maintained, and the scenery, though perhaps lacking the grandeur of some regions, possessed a quiet charm.” Mrs. Penhaligon, who considered the local scenery perfectly adequate, allowed a small smile to play upon her lips. “Oakhaven is not a place for those who require constant excitement, certainly. It offers, however, a degree of tranquility which many find most restorative.” The conversation proceeded in this vein, a polite dance of inquiry and response, during which Mrs. Penhaligon attempted, with a delicacy

text: she considered admirable, to ascertain Miss Ainsworth’s motives for choosing Oakhaven. It became clear that Miss Ainsworth had no particular connection to the village, nor any pressing need to reside in the countryside. She had, it seemed, simply desired a change. A desire, Mrs. Penhaligon thought, which bordered on the whimsical, and perhaps even a little imprudent. A lady’s life was, after all, generally dictated by duty and circumstance, not by the fleeting inclinations of her own heart. Miss Ainsworth’s independence, however, was not merely a matter of geographical relocation. It extended to her pursuits. She did not occupy herself with the usual feminine accomplishments – embroidery, pianoforte, or the delicate art of watercolour painting. Instead, she devoted her time to reading, to writing letters (a considerable number, judging by the frequency with which the post arrived), and, most surprisingly, to engaging in

text: discussions with Mr. Harding, the village schoolmaster, on matters of history and political philosophy. This last activity caused a considerable degree of consternation amongst the more conservative members of the community. It was, after all, quite improper for a lady to involve herself in such subjects, and even more improper to do so with a gentleman who lacked the social standing to offer her proper guidance. The situation was further complicated by the arrival of Mr. Frederick Beaumont, a gentleman of considerable fortune and impeccable lineage, who had taken a lease on the manor house. Mr. Beaumont, recently returned from several years abroad, was considered an
label: ai

text: eligible bachelor, and his presence in Oakhaven immediately set the local mothers to calculating the prospects of their daughters. It was generally assumed that Mr. Beaumont would, in due course, select a wife from amongst the eligible ladies of the neighbourhood, and Mrs. Penhaligon, along with many others, considered Miss Ainsworth to be entirely unsuitable. She lacked the connections, the fortune, and, most importantly, the temperament to make a suitable wife for a gentleman of Mr. Beaumont’s standing.
